body: A 15-year-old girl who escaped from custody Monday morning has been rearrested, the police said yesterday. The girl had been arrested at her home in Coney Island by officers of the Brooklyn Juvenile Crime Squad on a warrant for marijuana possession. When the patrol car stopped about 8 a.m. on Beverley Road, in Kensington, to pick up a second youth,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Escapee Is Rearrested

body: Rose Gelrod teaches gym in the lobby of Public School 63 in the South Bronx. She traces her own footprint with a green marker to outline a jogging path on the tile floor. End zones are drawn in pink around concrete pillars that subdivide the space. Classes, which include tai chi in the afternoons, are regularly interrupted by foot traffic to
title: Schools Pushing for Exercise, Even Without a Place to Play

body: A 15-year-old girl arrested on a drug warrant for marijuana possession escaped from a police car yesterday morning in the Kensington neighborhood, the police said. The girl slipped one hand out of her handcuffs, hit an officer in the head with them and fled. The girl's name was not released. The officer was treated at New York Methodist Hospital
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Escapes From Police Car

body: The memorandum from the New York City Department of Education went out to schools on Wednesday, and it seemed clear enough: ''No costumes, masks, or Halloween makeup should be worn while in school.'' It also said that parties were prohibited and that ''the customary Halloween tradition of 'trick or treat' should never take place.'' More than a few
title: Unspooked by Halloween Parties Memo, Schools Dress Up and Pass the Candy Bars

body: At the Kalmilata grocery and fish market on Church Avenue in the Kensington section of Brooklyn, the stack of Bengali-language weekly newspapers by the cash register had been thoroughly rifled through. A couple of copies remained of seven or eight newspapers, but one was already sold out. As customers came in asking for The Weekly Bangalee or
title: Immigrants With Ink in Their Blood; City's Bangladeshis Love to Read, and Many Newspapers Woo Them

body: A man who ran a makeshift mosque in the basement of his Brooklyn greeting-card store has been convicted of visa fraud in federal court for helping more than 200 illegal immigrants falsely obtain visas as religious workers. The man, Muhammad Khalil, 63, a naturalized American born in Pakistan, was the self-appointed imam of the Dar Ehya Essunnah
title: Man Who Led A Mosque Is Convicted Of Visa Fraud

body: ANDREASSEN--Gertrude. Age 86, on Thursday, August 19, 2004, of Rockville, MD, formerly of Sound Beach, NY and Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Gustav Andreassen. Mother of Carol Andreassen of Kensington, MD. Sister of Joan Fingeroth of Brooklyn, NY and aunt of James Fingeroth and Janet Roccanova, both of New York. A memorial service will be
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ANDREASSEN, GERTRUDE

body: JUST over two years ago, three dedicated New York bloggers posted a version of the city's subway map on the Internet and linked their online diaries to their nearest station. Then they sent a few e-mails inviting people to do the same. Three days later, the site crashed, inundated with Web authors marking their territory. As of last week, there
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ONLINE; By Their Subway Stations Ye Shall Know Them

body: MY FATHER'S FIGHTER By Ronald K. Fried Permanent Press ($24, hardcover) ''I think you should go backstage,'' Elizabeth tells me, as we are about to enter the former Felt Forum. We are just in front of the turnstiles that lead to the arena. ''It's called the dressing room,'' I say. ''Doesn't sound very masculine,'' Elizabeth says. ''What am I going
title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/NOVELS; From the Boxing Ring To the Nail Salon

body: There is widespread agreement among politicians in New York, where state legislators are rarely defeated once they get into office, that the best opportunity to beat an incumbent is in his or her first re-election campaign. That strategy appears to be playing out in a heated and emotional Democratic primary for the State Senate in a district
title: In Flatbush, 2 Challengers Work to Unseat a State Senator Before He Really Settles In

body: To the Editor: I thought ''Where Does She Live? The Suburbs, She Whispered'' was amusing, and I could relate to Leslie Kaufman's worries about losing street cred as a New Yorker living in the suburbs. But as a teacher and as someone who attended public schools here, I took offense at her characterization of New York City public schools. I realize
title: City or Suburbs? That Is the Question

body: A Roman Catholic priest who drew attention two years ago when he took to his Brooklyn pulpit to deny sexual abuse accusations was indicted yesterday on charges of abusing an 11-year-old altar boy the same year. In the spring of 2002, the priest, the Rev. Joseph P. Byrns, drew sympathy from some of his parishioners, and extensive news coverage, by
title: Priest Who Denied Sex Abuse Faces Charges in a New Case

body: To the Editor: My family agreed with just about everything in ''Charred Bubbles, and Other Secrets of the Slice'' (July 18). Domenico DeMarco of Di Fara Pizza is an artist, and every pizza he makes is an expression of his commitment to quality ingredients, making pizza the right (that is, his) way and the reciprocated love and respect he and the
title: Brooklyn's Pizza Master

body: WHEN Eric Griffith and his wife, Elizabeth, began looking for an apartment in Brooklyn at the beginning of 2001, they quickly became discouraged. For $350,000, they were finding 900-square-foot co-ops with no outdoor space and large maintenance fees. They considered buying a town house, living in one unit and renting out the remaining ones, but
title: Splitting The Cost Of Buying A House

body: WHEN Sarah Rose Kasowitz woke up on the first day of her life as a newly minted teacher, she poured her tea into a mug handed down from her grandmother. title: PUBLIC LIVES; From Acting to Unsung Role in Family's Tradition

body: WERE we going to London or Boy Scout camp? We weren't sure what we had gotten ourselves into months earlier when we made the reservation. Certainly, our family's mission could be defined as endless hiking, careful observation of intriguing new terrain and rollicking adventure scouting (or sightseeing, for that matter) at its most basic. Our chosen
title: A Trip Worthy of a Merit Badge

body: IN November, Miramax Books dispatched interns with stacks of postcards to deposit in Brooklyn bars and post on bulletin boards across Manhattan that left behind a cryptic question: ''Are you a love monkey or a booty nomad?'' In smaller type, they teased: ''Find out in February 2004.'' It may be a reach to say men have discovered their feelings, but
title: Oh, to Write A 'Bridget Jones' For Men: A Guy Can Dream

body: A listing in the Residential Sales column last Thursday for a limestone house at 295 East Seventh Street in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood. It is in Kensington, not Park Slope.
title: Corrections

body: FOR Belayet Hossain and his family, the promise of America will most likely end on Feb. 19. Like thousands of others, Mr. Hossain, a baker who lives in Kensington, Brooklyn, was picked up for violating his visa under a controversial aspect, now defunct, of a ''special registration'' program. This program, started in November 2002, required men from
title: CITYPEOPLE; Broken Promises
